content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose to play this game strategically. Since we don't know the opponent's strategy, I would adopt a mixed strategy. A mixed strategy involves choosing different actions with probabilities that add up to 1.

In this case, if I choose R with probability p and B with probability (1-p), my expected payoff per round is:

45p^2 + 0p(1-p) + 40p(1-p)^2 + 20(1-p)^2

To maximize my expected payoff, I would choose the value of p that makes this equation maximal.

After some calculations, we find that the maximum occurs when p = 1/3 (choosing R with a probability of 1/3 and B with a probability of 2/3). This strategy is called the Nash Equilibrium in game theory. It allows me to have a higher average payoff than if I were always choosing the same action, regardless of my opponent's choice.

So, my choice would be to play R with a probability of 1/3 and B with a probability of 2/3, appended as {R} in curly brackets as the last character.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, I have lost a round by choosing R while my opponent chose B. However, since the game has 75 rounds, and I adopted a mixed strategy with a probability of 1/3 to choose R, there are still many opportunities for me to win future rounds.

In the next round, I will stick to my mixed strategy and choose R or B randomly based on probabilities (1/3 and 2/3 respectively). My choice in this round will be appended as {R} or {B}, whichever I choose.
